title: Middlesex Co. Parks Launches Fall Volunteer Program for Conservation Projects
description: The department has organized three special volunteer events running from September through November.
content:
MIDDLESEX COUNTY, NJ - As autumn approaches, the Middlesex County Office of Parks and Recreation is calling on community members to roll up their sleeves and help preserve the county's natural treasures through a series of volunteer conservation projects.

The department has organized three special volunteer events running from September through November, each focusing on different aspects of environmental stewardship across the county's park system. The fall volunteer season kicks off on Saturday, Sept. 27, with National Public Lands Day at Ireland Brook Conservation Area in East Brunswick. From 9 a.m. to noon, volunteers will tackle trail maintenance and participate in ongoing restoration projects that help preserve this 581-acre natural space along Riva Avenue.

The conservation efforts continue on Saturday, October 18, with a Beach Sweep at Raritan Bay Waterfront Park in South Amboy. This shoreline cleanup, running from 9 a.m. to noon, is part of a statewide initiative organized in partnership with Clean Ocean Action. Located at 201 John T O'Leary Boulevard, Raritan Bay Waterfront Park provides crucial habitat for marine life and serves as a recreational destination for county residents. The beach sweep addresses the ongoing challenge of coastal pollution while raising awareness about marine conservation.

The volunteer season concludes on Saturday, Nov. 15, with Fall Trails Day at Davidson's Mill Pond Park in North Brunswick. This 9 a.m. to noon event focuses on trail maintenance and habitat improvement projects throughout the park's diverse ecosystems. Davidson's Mill Pond Park, located on Riva Avenue, encompasses wetlands, woodlands, and open spaces that provide habitat for various wildlife species. The Fall Trails Day activities help ensure these trails remain accessible and safe for the thousands of visitors who use them for hiking, birdwatching, and nature study.

Registration is required for all three events. Interested volunteers can contact Julia DeRosso at 732-745-8147 or email juliaderosso@co.middlesex.nj.us to sign up for any or all of the conservation projects. The parks department encourages volunteers of all ages and skill levels to participate, with activities suitable for families, groups, and individuals. Volunteers should dress appropriately for outdoor work and bring water bottles and sun protection.

summary: The Middlesex County Office of Parks and Recreation has initiated a fall volunteer program for conservation projects from September through November. The volunteer events will take place from September 27 to November 18, focusing on different aspects of environmental stewardship across the county's park system. The first event will be held at Ireland Brook Conservation Area in East Brunswick on September 27, with volunteers working on trail maintenance and restoration projects. The second event will take places at Raritan Bay Waterfront Park in South Amboy on October 18, with a beach sweep aimed at addressing coastal pollution and raising awareness about marine conservation. The final event will include Fall Trails Day at Davidson's Mill Pond Park in North Brunswick on Nov. 15. Registration is required for all three events.
shortSummary: Middlesex County Parks and Recreation launches a fall volunteer season, focusing on various environmental projects, with events starting on September 27 and November 15.

argos_summary: The Middlesex County Office of Parks and Recreation is inviting residents to volunteer in three conservation events from September to November. The first, National Public Lands Day on Sept. 27 at Ireland Brook Conservation Area, focuses on trail maintenance and restoration. The second, a Beach Sweep on Oct. 18 at Raritan Bay Waterfront Park, cleans the shoreline and raises marine conservation awareness. The final event, Fall Trails Day on Nov. 15 at Davidson's Mill Pond Park, works on trail upkeep and habitat improvement. Volunteers can register by contacting Julia DeRosso via phone or email.
